questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right ear pain for the past three months. The pain is constant, dull, and associated with recurrent right-sided jaw pain and headache. The pain worsens throughout the day and with chewing. He hears a “cracking sound” while eating. The patient’s partner says that he grinds his teeth at night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and muscle spasms over the lateral right face. Otoscopic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following nerves contributes to this patient’s ear pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ear pain, headache, and jaw pain are characteristic of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder. Underlying etiologies of this condition include pathological contraction of the pterygoid muscles secondary to repeated jaw clenching or grinding, misalignment, or trauma. Patients often develop hypersensitivity of the mandibular nerve (CV V3) and subsequent otalgia, given the nerve’s proximity to the TMJ. Classic symptoms include dull, waxing and waning jaw/facial pain, clicking and popping with jaw movement, ear pain, fullness, and tinnitus.

The mandibular nerve, the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensation to the TMJ in addition to the floor of the mouth, anterior tongue, and the lower face. In addition, this nerve contributes to sensory innervation to the external auditory canal. Therefore, TMJ disorder can also present with referred ear pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) carries general motor innervation to the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) carries sensory innervation from the external auditory canal; however, it is not the underlying cause of ear pain in this patient with temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Cervical spinal nerve  :
Incorrect: The cervical spinal nerve is harmed by structural lesions to the cervical spine. More commonly, damage to this nerve results in neck pain/stiffness and arm and shoulder weakness. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.
❌ Vestibulocochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) carries auditory and vestibular information from the inner ear. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a firm, nontender swelling over her right cheek for the past five months. The patient does not have a sore throat, runny nose, headache, or fever. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one glass of wine after dinner most nights. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fullness of the right preauricular space. An MRI of the face demonstrates a 3 cm mass of the right parotid gland, which is determined to be neoplastic on a subsequent core-needle biopsy. An elective parotidectomy is performed, and an important nerve embedded within the parotid gland is accidentally injured. Which of the following clinical features is the patient most likely to develop as a result of this injury?

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to close the right eye entirely
Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Down and out deviation of the right eye
Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a parotid gland neoplasm and underwent subsequent surgical excision of the parotid gland (parotidectomy). The facial nerve CN VII (parotid plexus) can be injured during parotidectomy or from compression by a parotid gland tumor. Damage to the CN VII or its branches will cause paralysis of the facial muscles, causing them to lose tone. The inferior eyelid can be particularly affected, resulting in an inability to close the eye entirely.

Similarly at risk during parotid pathologies, the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is closely related to the parotid gland and passes superior to it along with the superficial temporal vessels. The auriculotemporal nerve innervates the parotid sheath as well as the overlying skin. Therefore, patients with parotitis (parotid gland inflammation) often experience external auricular pain.


Option Analysis

❌ Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the genioglossus, which is responsible for tongue protrusion. CN XII is most frequently injured during carotid endarterectomy, which can result in ipsilateral genioglossus weakness with a deviation of the tongue toward the ipsilateral side with tongue protrusion. CNXII does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
✅ Inability to close the right eye entirely  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue  :
Incorrect: General sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by a branch of the trigeminal nerve. This nerve does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Down and out deviation of the right eye  :
Incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy causes down and out deviation of the eye. CN III does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field  :
Incorrect:  Homonymous hemianopia is a defect that affects half of the visual field due to a contralateral optic nerve (CN II) lesion posterior to the optic chiasm. CN II does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the embryology of the gastrointestinal tract and discovers an anatomical line called the pectinate line within the anal canal. Which of the following best characterizes the region of the anal canal above the pectinate line?

choices.text: Hemorrhoids in this region are painful
Arterial supply by the superior rectal artery
Somatic innervation by the pudendal nerve
Lymphatics drain into superficial inguinal lymph nodes
Veins drain into the inferior vena cava

questions.solution:
The anal canal extends from the anorectal junction at the pelvic diaphragm to the anal orifice. The pectinate line, also termed dentate line, divides the anal canal into upper and lower parts. Above the pectinate line, the anal canal is supplied by the superior rectal artery and innervated by the inferior hypogastric plexus. Below the pectinate line, the anal canal is supplied by the middle and inferior rectal arteries and innervated by the inferior rectal nerves, which are branches of the pudendal nerve. The differences between the two regions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Hemorrhoids in this region are painful  :
Incorrect: Internal hemorrhoids (in the region above the pectinate line) receive visceral innervation and are typically not painful.  
✅ Arterial supply by the superior rectal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatic innervation by the pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: The region above the pectinate line is innervated primarily by the inferior hypogastric plexus. In contrast, the pudendal nerve innervates the region below the pectinate line.  
❌ Lymphatics drain into superficial inguinal lymph nodes  :
Incorrect: The region of the anal canal above the pectinate line drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes.  
❌ Veins drain into the inferior vena cava  :
Incorrect: The region of the anal canal above the pectinate lines drains into the portal vein. In contrast, the region below the anal canal drains into the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the gastrointestinal ligament and the structures housed within. They discover the hepatoduodenal ligament contains the portal triad, which consists of the proper hepatic artery, hepatic portal vein, and common bile duct. Which of the following structures form the hepatic portal vein?

choices.text: Inferior mesenteric and superior mesenteric veins
External iliac and internal iliac veins

questions.solution:
The hepatic portal vein is a short, wide vein that is formed by the superior mesenteric and splenic veins posterior to the neck of the pancreas. It ascends anterior to the inferior vena cava (IVC) as part of the portal triad in the hepatoduodenal ligament. The portal triad consists of the hepatic artery (carries oxygenated blood to the liver), hepatic portal vein (carries blood with nutrients and toxins extracted from digested content to the liver), and bile duct (carries bile products away from hepatocytes and towards the larger ducts and gallbladder).  



Option Analysis

❌ Collecting and central veins  :
Incorrect: The hepatic veins, not the hepatic portal vein, are formed by the union of collecting veins that in turn drain the central veins of the hepatic parenchyma. The hepatic veins then open into the inferior vena cava (IVC), just inferior to the diaphragm.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric and superior mesenteric veins  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein, which then joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the hepatic portal vein.  
✅ Superior mesenteric and splenic veins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric and splenic veins  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein, which then joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the hepatic portal vein.  
❌ External iliac and internal iliac veins  :
Incorrect: The external iliac vein and internal iliac vein unite anterior of the sacroiliac joint to form the common iliac veins.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the autonomic pathways of the gastrointestinal system. Which of the following best characterizes parasympathetic innervation of the hindgut?
questions.solution:
The nerve supply to the gastrointestinal tract can be divided into intrinsic innervation, which controls digestive activity, and extrinsic innervation, which provides sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation.

The foregut and midgut receive parasympathetic innervation from the vagus nerve, whereas the hindgut receives parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4).  

Option Analysis

❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut.  
❌ Inferior hypogastric plexus  :
Incorrect: The inferior hypogastric plexus has both parasympathetic and sympathetic components and innervates the internal pelvic viscera.  
❌ Lesser splanchnic nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser splanchnic nerve (T9-T12) provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut.  
❌ Greater splanchnic nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater splanchnic nerve (T5-T10) provides sympathetic innervation to the foregut.  
✅ Pelvic splanchnic nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing a sleeve gastrectomy. The procedure involves removing a large portion of the stomach along the middle part of the greater curvature. Which of the following major arteries supplies this region of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the gastroepiploic artery, a branch of splenic artery that arises from the celiac trunk.

Embryologically, the gastrointestinal tract is divided into the foregut, midgut, and hindgut. Each gut region is supplied by a distinct major artery. The arterial supply of the gastrointestinal tract is summarized below:  




Option Analysis

✅ Celiac trunk  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior mesenteric artery  :
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery is the second anterior branch of the abdominal aorta. It supplies midgut structures from the distal duodenum to proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric artery  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric artery is the third anterior branch of the abdominal aorta. It supplies the hindgut structures from the distal one-third of the transverse colon to the upper portion of the anal canal.  
❌ Thoracic aorta:
Incorrect: The stomach is supplied by branches of the abdominal aorta, not the thoracic aorta.  
❌ External iliac artery  :
Incorrect: The external iliac artery supplies blood to the lower extremities. It passes down along the brim of the pelvis and gives off two large branches, the inferior epigastric artery and the deep circumflex artery. These vessels supply the muscles and skin in the lower abdominal wall. The external iliac artery does not, however, provide blood supply to the stomach.

questions.text: A partial liver resection is performed in a patient with an early stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. During the procedure, a ligament is found that attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall. Which of the following structures are contained within this ligament?

choices.text: Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct
Remnant of the fetal umbilical vein

questions.solution:
The falciform ligament attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall. It is derived from the ventral mesentery and contains the ligamentum teres hepatis, which is a remnant of the fetal umbilical vein, and patent paraumbilical veins. Other gastrointestinal ligaments are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct  :
Incorrect: The portal triad consists of the hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct. The portal vein is contained within the hepatoduodenal ligament, which connects the liver to the duodenum.  
✅ Remnant of the fetal umbilical vein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tail of the pancreas  :
Incorrect: The tail of the pancreas is contained within the splenorenal ligament, which connects the spleen to the left pararenal space.  
❌ Gastroepiploic arteries  :
Incorrect: The gastroepiploic arteries are contained within the gastrocolic ligament, which connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the transverse colon.  
❌ Short gastric vessels  :
Incorrect: The short gastric vessels are contained within the gastrosplenic ligament, which connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the origin and blood supply of different regions of the gastrointestinal tract. The blood vessel that supplies the hindgut originates at which of the following vertebral levels?
questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta that originates at the L3 level and supplies the hindgut. The IMA branches into the left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries.  Other branches of the abdominal aorta are summarized below:  




Option Analysis

❌ T12/L1  :
Incorrect: The celiac artery supplies the foregut and branches off from the aorta at the T12/L1 vertebral level. The celiac artery then branches into the common hepatic, splenic, and left gastric arteries.  
❌ L1  :
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supplies the midgut. It branches off the aorta at the L1 vertebral level.  
❌ L1-L2  :
Incorrect: The renal arteries are a pair of vessels that arise from the abdominal aorta at the level of the inferior border of the L1 vertebra. Each renal artery directly supplies the ipsilateral kidney and gives rise to an inferior suprarenal artery, which supplies the adrenal gland.  
✅ L3  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L1-L4  :
Incorrect: The lumbar arteries are a series of paired arteries (usually four pairs) that arise from the abdominal aorta at the levels of L1-L4. They supply the lumbar segments of the spinal cord and the posterior abdominal wall, but not the hindgut.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle accident. Physical examination reveals numerous ecchymoses over the trunk and flanks, as well as a tender right abdomen without a palpable mass. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no intraperitoneal fluid collections. The hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL. Which of the following organs is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has a low hemoglobin level, but the FAST exam is negative for intraperitoneal fluid collections. These findings, along with right-sided flank pain, are concerning for a retroperitoneal bleed, secondary to kidney injury.

Retroperitoneal structures are posterior to (and outside of) the peritoneal cavity. Injuries to retroperitoneal structures can cause blood or gas accumulation in the retroperitoneal space. These structures can be remembered by the mnemonic SAD PUCKER:

Suprarenal (adrenal) glands, Aorta/IVC, Duodenum (except for the first part), Pancreas (except for the tail), Ureters, Colon (ascending and descending parts), Kidneys, Esophagus, Rectum.  

Option Analysis

❌ Liver  :
Incorrect: The liver is an intraperitoneal organ. Traumatic liver bleeds should result in free intraperitoneal fluid on a FAST exam.  
❌ Spleen  :
Incorrect: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ. Traumatic spleen rupture should result in free intraperitoneal fluid on a FAST exam.  
✅ Kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stomach  :
Incorrect: Injury to the stomach may explain this patient's physical examination findings. However, since the stomach is an intraperitoneal organ, intraperitoneal fluid collections would likely be visualized on a FAST exam.  
❌ Ileum  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ileum may explain this patient's physical examination findings. However, since the ileum is an intraperitoneal organ, intraperitoneal fluid collections would likely be visualized on a FAST exam.

questions.text:
A histological section of the esophagus is taken from a healthy patient and examined under microscopy. The gastroesophageal junction is noted in this histological section, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding the gastroesophageal junction?  

Source: Histology guide

choices.text: Here, the epithelium changes from non-keratinized stratified squamous to columnar epithelium
It is considered an anatomical junction
Here, the epithelium changes from columnar to keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to columnar
Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) is a physiological junction between the esophagus and the stomach. It is marked by histological changes in the mucosal lining between the esophagus and the stomach.

In the GEJ, the cells lining the mucosa change from the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to the simple columnar epithelium of the stomach. This transition can be noted at the GEJ. The other change that can be seen after this junction is that there will be less connective tissue between the glands of the stomach's mucosa.


Option Analysis

✅ Here, the epithelium changes from non-keratinized stratified squamous to columnar epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is considered an anatomical junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is considered to be a physiological junction, not an anatomical junction.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from columnar to keratinized stratified squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to columnar  :
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium  :
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the biopsy specimen from a region of the gastrointestinal tract. Histologically, this area of the digestive tract contains crypts of Lieberkuhn and many goblet cells and lacks villi. Which of the following segments of the digestive tract is the investigator most likely studying?
questions.solution:
The colon makes up the longest part of the large intestine. It begins from the caecum at the ileocecal valve and ends in the rectum. The colon can be distinguished histologically from the small intestine based on the absence of villi in the former. Crypts of Lieberkuhn, enteroendocrine cells, and many goblet cells are also present in the colon.  


Option Analysis

✅ Colon:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The duodenum is histologically characterized by abundant villi and microvilli, Brunner glands (bicarbonate-secreting cells), and crypts of Lieberkuhn.  
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus is histologically characterized by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Crypts of Lieberkuhn and goblet cells are not present.  
❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: The ileum of the small intestine is histologically characterized by villi, Peyer patches, plicae circulares, crypts of Lieberkuhn, and an abundance of goblet cells.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: The jejunum is histologically characterized by villi, plicae circulares, and crypts of Lieberkuhn.

questions.text:
A histological sample is collected from an area in the gastrointestinal tract to identify the different types of cells and structures. The picture of the sample under the microscope is shown below. To which part of the gastrointestinal tract does this sample most likely belong?
 

Source: histological guide
questions.solution:
The gastrointestinal tract has histological features that can be similar in different parts, but quite a few differences help distinguish other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

In the proximal duodenum, specifically the first part of the duodenum, the Brunner glands can be visualized, which are submucosal glands (arrow in picture). The function of these glands is to form a mucous layer to protect the duodenal lining from acid damage. The secretions from these glands are alkaline, which also helps neutralize the acidity of the food coming from the stomach.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ First part of the duodenum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Last part of the duodenum  :
Incorrect: The sample in the picture above shows Brunner glands, only found in the proximal duodenum.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: The histological sample of the jejunum usually contains enterocytes and goblet cells. Brunner glands are not seen in the jejunum.  
❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: The histological sample of the ileum usually contains small collections of lymphatic tissue (Peyer patches) in addition to the villous architecture. It does not have Brunner glands like the first part of the duodenum.  
❌ Stomach:
Incorrect: Villi and the Brunner gland suggest that this sample was taken from the proximal duodenum, not the stomach, which does not contain either. A microscopic examination of the stomach shows gastric glands in the mucosa.

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating the histological features of the gastrointestinal tract. In one section of the ileum, he finds a group of specialized cells in nodules in the submucosal layer, as shown in the image below (red circle). Which of the following is the function of this structure?  

Source: Wikimedia commons

choices.text: They help in identifying antigens and producing antibodies.
They assist in the digestion of fat.
They assist in the breakdown of proteins.

questions.solution:
Peyer’s patches are a group of well-organized lymphoid follicles found mainly in the ileum but also in the duodenum and jejunum. Histologically, they are found in the lamina propria and the submucosa.

These patches are specialized immune structures that mainly contain B-cells. However, it also includes T-cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells. In addition, a particular type of cell called microfold cells (M cells) is found in these patches, which function as antigen-presenting cells. Once M cells encounter a pathogen, they activate dendritic cells and macrophages, which, in turn, activate lymphocytes leading to the amplification of immune response and production of IgA antibodies (by B-lymphocytes). These antibodies finally travel to the gut lumen to fight the intraluminal pathogens.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ They help in identifying antigens and producing antibodies.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ They secrete an alkaline solution.:
Incorrect: Peyer’s patches are specialized immune structures containing lymphoid cell follicles. Brunner’s glands are secretory glands that produce alkaline mucus. They do not secrete alkaline solutions.  
❌ They assist in peristalsis.  :
Incorrect: Peristalsis is mediated by the muscularis layer. Peyer’s patches are not involved in the peristalsis.  
❌ They assist in the digestion of fat.  :
Incorrect: Digestion of fat involves pancreatic enzymes and bile. However, Peyer's patches are not involved in the digestion process.  
❌ They assist in the breakdown of proteins.  :
Incorrect: Protein digestion involves gastric acid and enzymes and pancreatic enzymes. Peyer’s patches are not involved in the digestion process.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of liver parenchyma. Under histological examination, the liver parenchyma is divided into hexagonal hepatic lobules containing the central vein in the center and the portal triad at the periphery. Each hepatic lobule is divided into three different zones. The circled zone in the picture is most susceptible to which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
The liver parenchyma is divided into hepatic lobules, consisting of a central vein in the center and the portal triad (bile duct, hepatic arteriole, and portal venule) at the periphery. Each lobule receives a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and the portal vein, and the blood drains from the periphery to the central vein through the hepatic sinusoids.    

Each hepatic lobule is divided into 3 main zones:  
  1.  Zone 1 (periportal zone): This zone surrounds the portal triad and receives the highest oxygen supply. This zone is most resistant (not susceptible) to ischemic injury. Zone 1 is most susceptible to viral hepatitis and cocaine injury.  
  2.  Zone 2 (intermediate zone): This zone is located between zone 1 and zone 3 and is susceptible to injury from yellow fever.  
  3. Zone 3 (the pericentral zone): This zone surrounds the central vein in the center of the hepatic lobule. Because hepatocytes in this zone are furthest from the blood supply, they receive a lesser oxygen concentration than in zone 1 and 2. Therefore, zone 3 is the earliest to be affected by ischemia. Additionally, this zone contains high concentrations of metabolic enzymes (e.g. cytochrome P450 enzymes), and is also most affected by metabolic toxins (e.g.- alcohol). 

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatitis A virus:
Incorrect: Zone 1 (the periportal zone) is most susceptible to viral hepatitis, not zone 3.
❌ Yellow fever:
Incorrect: Yellow fever affects mostly zone 2 (the intermediate zone).
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Zone 1 is the most susceptible for injury from cocaine.
❌ Hepatitis C virus:
Incorrect: Zone 1 (the periportal zone) is the most susceptible to viral hepatitis, not zone 3.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of liver parenchyma. It is found to be divided into hexagonal-shaped hepatic lobules. At the periphery of each lobule, the structures below are identified. Which of the following best describes the function of Label A in the image?

choices.text: Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the portal vein
Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery
Lymphatic drainage from the hepatic parenchyma

questions.solution:
The liver parenchyma is organized into hexagonal-shaped lobules called hepatic lobules. These lobules are the functional unit of the liver. Each lobule receives a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and the portal vein, and the blood is drained into the centrally located central vein. The lobule contains many hepatocytes that perform a variety of functions.  

At the periphery of each hepatic lobule, there is the portal triad. The portal triad consists of a portal venule, hepatic arteriole, and bile ductule. The portal venule supplies blood from the portal vein, and is identified with its narrow lumen and thin walls. The hepatic arteriole, on the other hand, has thicker walls and narrower lumen and supplies blood from the hepatic artery. Finally, the bile ductule, which is responsible for collecting bile from the bile canaliculi, is identified by its prominent simple cuboidal epithelium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the portal vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Collect bile from the hepatocytes  :
Incorrect: The bile ductule (Label B) located in the portal triad is responsible for bile collection from the bile canaliculi that collects bile produced by the hepatocytes.  
❌ Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery:
Incorrect: The hepatic arteriole (Label C) provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery  
❌ Lymphatic drainage from the hepatic parenchyma:
Incorrect: There are lymphatic vessels (Label D) located in the portal triad that are responsible for lymphatic drainage. However, they have a narrower lumen than the portal venule.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate chest and abdominal pain, typically after eating large meals. Biochemical testing reveals markedly elevated gastrin levels. In addition to increased gastric acid secretion, which of the following is also expected to happen in this patient due to increased gastrin levels?

choices.text: Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Gastrin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the G-cells, which are mainly in the pyloric antrum of the stomach but can also be found in the small intestines and pancreas. Gastrin’s primary functions are in the gastrointestinal tract.  

Gastrin is responsible for increasing gastric acid secretions, both directly and indirectly. It does this directly by binding to cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptors on parietal cells, enhancing the activity of the H+/K+ ATPase pumps and ultimately increasing acid secretion into the gastric lumen. It also does this indirectly by stimulating enterochromaffin-like cells (ECL) to produce histamine, which then promotes acid secretion.  

In addition, gastrin also has other functions, such as increasing gastric motility and stimulating the growth and proliferation of gastric mucosa.  

Gastrin secretion is increased by vagal stimulation (through gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP)), stomach distention, increased pH of the stomach, and the presence of amino acids in the stomach. In contrast, the secretion of gastrin is inhibited by low stomach pH via negative feedback.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of gastric mucosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased gastric motility:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric motility.
❌ Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion, which is expected to cause increases in the bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine to help neutralize the incoming gastric acid.  
❌ Increased appetite  :
Incorrect: Gastrin does not affect appetite.  
❌ Decreased histamine secretion  :
Incorrect: Gastrin directly stimulates enterochromaffin-like cells in the stomach to secrete histamine to maximize gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: A synthetic analog of a hormone produced by the body is being studied for use in weight loss. In the study, the synthetic hormone is shown to decrease fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. During a 6-month evaluation after initiating treatment, it was noted that there was an increased incidence of diabetes mellitus and gallstone formation in subjects receiving the hormone. The analog used in this trial is most similar to which of the following physiological hormones?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is a primary regulatory hormone that is produced throughout the body. In the gastrointestinal tract, somatostatin is produced by the D-cells found at several locations in the digestive system, namely the pyloric antrum, duodenum, and pancreatic islets.  

Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone, and in the gastrointestinal tract, it inhibits various secretions, including exocrine secretions such as bile, gastric acid, pancreatic secretions, colonic fluid, cholecystokinin, and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). Due to its inhibition of cholecystokinin, a hormone that causes gallbladder contractions, somatostatin causes bile stasis. Therefore, octreotide can increase the risk of gallstone formation. Additionally, somatostatin inhibits endocrine secretions of insulin and glucagon from the pancreas.  

The inhibitory effects of somatostatin, specifically via its analogs like octreotide, make its use beneficial in various pathological conditions, such as gastrinoma, VIPoma, and carcinoid syndrome. However, somatostatin has a very short half-life, so synthetic analogs with longer half-lives are used (e.g. octreotide).  

Option Analysis

✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid production, which may damage the villi of the intestines and decrease fat absorption. However, it is not associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus or gallstones.  
❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin increases fat absorption by stimulating gallbladder contraction and bile secretion into the intestines. Additionally, it decreases the risk of gallstone formation.
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin increases fat absorption by stimulating bile and pancreatic secretions.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)  :
Incorrect: VIP does not inhibit the absorption of fat.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate chest and abdominal pain, typically after eating large meals. Biochemical testing reveals markedly elevated gastrin levels. In addition to increased gastric acid secretion, which of the following is also expected to happen in this patient due to increased gastrin levels?

choices.text: Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Gastrin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the G-cells, which are mainly in the pyloric antrum of the stomach but can also be found in the small intestines and pancreas. Gastrin’s primary functions are in the gastrointestinal tract.  

Gastrin is responsible for increasing gastric acid secretions, both directly and indirectly. It does this directly by binding to cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptors on parietal cells, enhancing the activity of the H+/K+ ATPase pumps and ultimately increasing acid secretion into the gastric lumen. It also does this indirectly by stimulating enterochromaffin-like cells (ECL) to produce histamine, which then promotes acid secretion.  

In addition, gastrin also has other functions, such as increasing gastric motility and stimulating the growth and proliferation of gastric mucosa.   

Gastrin secretion is increased by vagal stimulation (through gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP)), stomach distention, increased pH of the stomach, and the presence of amino acids in the stomach. In contrast, the secretion of gastrin is inhibited by low stomach pH via negative feedback.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of gastric mucosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased gastric motility  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric motility.  
❌ Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion, which is expected to cause increases in the bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine to help neutralize the incoming gastric acid.  
❌ Increased appetite  :
Incorrect: Gastrin does not affect appetite.  
❌ Decreased histamine secretion  :
Incorrect: Gastrin directly stimulates enterochromaffin-like cells in the stomach to secrete histamine to maximize gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: A researcher is performing a histological examination of the gastrointestinal tract. Several cell types are identified and studied. The researchers isolate a group of cells called S cells, which are found in the duodenum. These cells produce a hormone that exerts the following effects?

choices.text: Increases insulin secretion from the pancreas

questions.solution:
Secretin is a peptide hormone with many physiological effects in the gastrointestinal tract. It is produced by S cells in the duodenum, and the presence of gastric acid and fatty acids in the duodenal lumen stimulates its release.  

Secretin acts on the pancreatic acinar cells to stimulate the production and release of bicarbonate (HCO3-). It also increases bicarbonate release in the bile and from the Brenner glands in the duodenum.  

These effects are crucial to neutralize the acidity of gastric fluid and elevating the pH in the lumen of the duodenum to provide an optimal environment for the digestion of fat and protect the duodenum from acidic damage. In addition, secretin stimulates the secretion of bile, which helps in the digestion of fat. Finally, secretin inhibits gastric acid release.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stimulates pancreatic HCO3- secretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stimulates gallbladder contraction:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin stimulates gallbladder contraction. It is produced by I cells in the small intestine, not S cells.  
❌ Increases insulin secretion from the pancreas  :
Incorrect: Glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) stimulates the secretion of insulin. It is produced by K cells in the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum of the gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Inhibits pancreatic secretions  :
Incorrect: Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic secretions and is produced by D cells in the pancreas and small intestine.  
❌ Stimulates gastric acid secretion  :
Incorrect: G cells release gastrin, which stimulates gastric acid secretion. In contrast, S cells release secretin and decrease gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: A synthetic analog of a hormone produced by the body is being studied for use in weight loss. In the study, the synthetic hormone is shown to decrease fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. During a 6-month evaluation after initiating treatment, it was noted that there was an increased incidence of diabetes mellitus and gallstone formation in subjects receiving the hormone. The analog used in this trial is most similar to which of the following physiological hormones?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is a primary regulatory hormone that is produced throughout the body. In the gastrointestinal tract, somatostatin is produced by the D-cells found at several locations in the digestive system, namely the pyloric antrum, duodenum, and pancreatic islets.  

Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone, and in the gastrointestinal tract, it inhibits various secretions, including exocrine secretions such as bile, gastric acid, pancreatic secretions, colonic fluid, cholecystokinin, and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). Due to its inhibition of cholecystokinin, a hormone that causes gallbladder contractions, somatostatin causes bile stasis. Therefore, octreotide can increase the risk of gallstone formation. Additionally, somatostatin inhibits endocrine secretions of insulin and glucagon from the pancreas.  

The inhibitory effects of somatostatin, specifically via its analogs like octreotide, make its use beneficial in various pathological conditions, such as gastrinoma, VIPoma, and carcinoid syndrome. However, somatostatin has a very short half-life, so synthetic analogs with longer half-lives are used (e.g. octreotide).  

Option Analysis

✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid production, which may damage the villi of the intestines and decrease fat absorption. However, it is not associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus or gallstones.  
❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin increases fat absorption by stimulating gallbladder contraction and bile secretion into the intestines. Additionally, it decreases the risk of gallstone formation.  
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin increases fat absorption by stimulating bile and pancreatic secretions.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)  :
Incorrect: VIP does not inhibit the absorption of fat.

questions.text: A group of investigators discovered special cells in the enteric nervous system that generate slow wave potentials in the intestinal tract. These cells are most appropriately described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the myenteric plexus, act like pacemaker cells in the heart. Cajal cells generate rhythmic depolarization and repolarization of the cell membrane, called slow-wave potentials, without any external stimulation from the neural or endocrine system.  

The depolarization of the Cajal cells is caused by the opening of slow sodium channels in the cell membrane which cause an influx of sodium ions, while repolarization is caused by the opening of potassium channels which allow for an efflux of potassium. Cajal cells are connected to smooth muscle cells via gap junctions which allow the slow wave potential to travel through the smooth muscles triggering voltage-gated ca2+ (calcium) channels to open, sparking depolarization of the smooth muscle cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ Keratinocytes:
Incorrect: Keratinocytes are the predominant cells in the epidermis, which are constantly generated in the basal lamina and go through maturation, differentiation, and migration to the surface. These are not found in the enteric nervous system.  
❌ Neuroglia:
Incorrect: Neuroglia is a diverse class of cells that provide developmental, physiological, and metabolic support for neurons. They are responsible for maintaining homeostatic control and immune surveillance in the nervous system. These are not found in the enteric nervous system.  
❌ Enterochromaffin (EC) cells  :
Incorrect: Enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the intestinal mucosa sense a food bolus, and in response, secrete serotonin (5-HT) which binds to primary afferent neuron receptors to activate the peristalsis reflex. It is, however, not a part of the enteric nervous system and does not generate slow wave potentials.  
✅ Interstitial cells of Cajal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Parietal cells  :
Incorrect: Parietal cells are found in the stomach where they secrete hydrochloric acid.  It is, however, not a part of the enteric nervous system and does not generate slow wave potential.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the innervation of the gastrointestinal system. She discovers that the gastrointestinal tract has intrinsic innervations, specifically, the enteric nervous system, and extrinsic innervations; specifically, the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervations. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the enteric nervous system?

choices.text: The enteric nervous system cannot function without extrinsic innervation
The enteric nervous system is made up of four different plexuses
The Meissner’s plexus is found between the longitudinal muscle layer and the circular muscle layer
The Auerbach’s plexus is found in the submucosa
The ganglia in the Auerbach’s plexus are in charge of gastric motility

questions.solution:
The gastrointestinal tract has intrinsic and extrinsic innervation. The intrinsic component is the enteric nervous system and the extrinsic component is the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation which come from the central nervous system.  

The enteric nervous system has complex networks of afferent and efferent nerve fibers. It can operate independently of the brain and the spinal cord, but its activity is usually modulated by the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems. It is found within the walls of the entire gastrointestinal tract and is made up of two different plexuses.

- The submucosal or Meissner’s plexus: located in the submucosa, it functions to promote gastrointestinal secretions for digestion.  
- The myenteric or Auerbach’s plexus: located within the muscularis externa, between the longitudinal muscle layer and the circular muscle layer, the ganglia in the Auerbach’s plexus are in charge of gastric motility.  


Option Analysis

❌ The enteric nervous system cannot function without extrinsic innervation  :
Incorrect: The enteric nervous system can function without extrinsic innervation.  
❌ The enteric nervous system is made up of four different plexuses  :
Incorrect: The enteric nervous system is made up of two different plexuses: the Meissner’s plexus and Auerbach’s plexus.  
❌ The Meissner’s plexus is found between the longitudinal muscle layer and the circular muscle layer  :
Incorrect: The Auerbach’s plexus is found between the longitudinal muscle layer and the circular muscle layer.  
❌ The Auerbach’s plexus is found in the submucosa  :
Incorrect: The Meissner’s plexus is found in the submucosa.  
✅ The ganglia in the Auerbach’s plexus are in charge of gastric motility  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate episodic right upper quadrant pain. The pain comes a few hours after eating a meal, especially fatty meals, and lasts for 3-4 hours. The pain is colicky. Ultrasound reveals a stone in the cystic duct. The pain is triggered mainly due to the secretion of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
This patient has gallstones, and the colicky pain is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction. Gallbladder contraction is mediated by cholecystokinin (CCK).

CCK is a peptide hormone produced by the I cells in the small intestine, specifically, the duodenum and jejunum. The presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the lumen of the small intestines stimulates the secretion of CCK.  

CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction to release bile into the intestine. It also stimulates pancreatic secretions, which help in the digestion of fat while mediating the relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow these juices to reach the intestine. Finally, CCK decreases gastric emptying.   

Option Analysis

❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin stimulates the secretions of pancreatic fluid and bile. However, it does not mediate gallbladder contraction.  
✅ Cholecystokinin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatostatin:
Incorrect: Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of various hormones in the gastrointestinal tract, including cholecystokinin. Therefore, using somatostatin analogs octreotide) can predispose to the formation of gallstones. However, biliary colic is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction, which is mediated by cholecystokinin.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin is not related to gallbladder contraction.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)   :
Incorrect: VIP is not related to gallbladder contraction.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old male is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation for jaundice. He was born at 40 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient’s blood is B, Rh D-negative. His mother’s blood is AB, Rh D-positive. The patient has been exclusively breastfed, produces 6-7 wet diapers per day, and has passed meconium. He is at the 70th percentile for weight and height. Physical examination shows scleral icterus as well as yellowing of the skin of the head and chest. The remainder of the exam is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Total bilirubin  9.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Hemoglobin  17.1 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,500/mm3 
Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Destruction of neonatal erythrocytes by maternal antibodies
Breakdown of blood accumulated under the scalp
Fibro-obliterative destruction of the biliary tracts

questions.solution:
This patient has physiologic jaundice of the newborn, a common condition that manifests within 2-7 days after birth. The condition is often seen in preterm infants and Asian newborns.  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn is caused by three factors. First, fetal erythrocytes have shorter lifespans. As a result, more unconjugated bilirubin gets produced. Second, newborn livers have immature UDP-glucuronyl transferase that is inefficient in conjugating bilirubin. Third, there is increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. This phenomenon is because there is a lower concentration of bacteria in neonatal digestive tracts, and therefore there is less intestinal bacterial conversion of conjugated bilirubin to urobilin, which is excreted via urine. As a result, more conjugated bilirubin is broken down into unconjugated bilirubin by beta-glucuronidase (an intestinal enzyme) and reabsorbed.  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn is usually a benign condition that resolves in 1-2 weeks. Most cases do not require treatment. In severe cases, treatment with non-UV phototherapy is used to isomerize unconjugated bilirubin into a water-soluble form that can be excreted via urine. This therapy prevents kernicterus, which occurs when large amounts of unconjugated bilirubin deposit in the brain and cause neurological damage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Destruction of neonatal erythrocytes by maternal antibodies:
Incorrect: This describes ABO and Rh-incompatibility. Both of these conditions occur when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and attack fetal red blood cells, resulting in their lysis. However, this patient’s mother is unlikely to produce anti-D antibodies (given she is Rh D-positive) or anti-B antibodies (given she is AB positive).
❌ Insufficient breast milk intake:
Incorrect: This describes breastfeeding failure jaundice, which occurs secondary to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin by stool. This leads to increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin and an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, this patient is producing 6-7 wet diapers per day, which indicates that he is well-hydrated and successfully breastfeeding. A helpful tip in determining the minimum number of wet diapers in the first week of life is that it is usually equivalent to the number of days since birth (e.g. a 5-day-old infant should produce 5 wet diapers/day). 
❌ Breakdown of blood accumulated under the scalp :
Incorrect: Breakdown of blood in a cephalohematoma can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The condition is often caused by shearing forces during vacuum or forceps delivery. In contrast, this patient had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Moreover, no scalp swelling was found on physical exam.
✅ Reduced hepatic conjugation of bilirubin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibro-obliterative destruction of the biliary tracts:
Incorrect: This describes biliary atresia, a condition wherein fibrosis results in destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Individuals will have jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools. However, biliary atresia would cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, whereas this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A group of investigators discover that both bile salts and bilirubin can be recycled via enterohepatic circulation. Which of the following is the primary site of bile salt reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Bile acids are efficiently conserved under normal conditions. Because bile acids are ionized, they cannot cross the intestine wall passively. The uptake of the conjugated bile acids is coupled to that of sodium by the activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase in the distal ileum. The transporter that mediates this uptake is the apical sodium-dependent bile salt transporter (ASBT). The reabsorbed bile acids enter the portal bloodstream and are taken up rapidly by hepatocytes, reconjugated, and resecreted into bile (enterohepatic circulation). Typically, the bile acid pool circulates ~5–10 times daily. Intestinal reabsorption of the pool is about 95% efficient; therefore, fecal loss of bile acids is in the range of 0.2–0.4 g/d. In the steady-state, this fecal loss is compensated by an equal daily synthesis of bile acids by the liver; thus, the size of the bile acid pool is maintained.  

Malabsorptive conditions like Crohn's disease can decrease enteric bile salts' reabsorption at the distal ileum. This prevents normal fat absorption and may cause bile acid diarrhea.


Option Analysis

❌ Ampulla of duodenum:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The bile is not secreted in the first part of the duodenum and, therefore, cannot be reabsorbed here.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The jejunum is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption.  
✅ Distal ileum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: Only a minor portion of the bile acid pool spills into the colon in healthy individuals. In the colon, bile is deconjugated and can be absorbed passively. The colon is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption.  
❌ Descending colon:
Incorrect: Only a minor portion of the bile acid pool spills into the colon in healthy individuals. The colon is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption. In the colon, it is deconjugated and can be absorbed passively.

questions.text: A patient with a past medical history of Crohn disease has recurrent nephrolithiasis episodes; urinalysis recurrently shows envelope-shaped crystals. Which of the following is this patient's most likely underlying cause of recurrent nephrolithiasis?

choices.text: Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis
The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+

questions.solution:
Malabsorptive conditions can decrease enteric bile salts' reabsorption at the distal ileum. Calcium, which normally chelates free oxalate, binds free lipids. More free oxalate is absorbed, which promotes the formation of renal calcium oxalate stones. This prevents fat absorption leading to fatty stool/bile acid diarrhea.  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased absorption of bile salts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired intestinal ornithine reabsorption:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive cystinuria is a hereditary defect of the proximal convoluted tubule in nephrons and small intestine (amino acid transport proteins). These defects prevent proper reabsorption of ornithine, cysteine, lysine, and arginine in the small intestine and the kidneys. This leads to the precipitation of hexagonal-shaped cystine stones in the urine, not envelope-shaped crystals.  
❌ Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis:
Incorrect: Urease-producing bacteria are a group of pathogens that can cause urinary tract infection and are responsible for forming ammonium magnesium phosphate stones, also called struvite stones. It is not envelope-shaped and is less likely than calcium oxalate stones (envelope-shaped crystals) in a patient with Crohn disease.  
❌ Increased urine homocysteine levels:
Incorrect: Homocystinuria is caused by enzyme deficiencies that increase blood and urine homocysteine levels. The condition is not associated with kidney stone formation.  
❌ The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+:
Incorrect: The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+ can be seen in distal renal tubular acidosis. Patients with this condition are at increased risk for renal calcium phosphate stones, which are wedge-shaped, not enveloped-shaped crystals.

questions.text: It is known that bilirubin gives bile its color. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the formation and secretion of bilirubin?

choices.text: The bilirubin released in the blood from macrophages is water-soluble.
Uridine glucuronyl transferase conjugates the bilirubin in the liver
Bilirubin is formed via glycosylation of erythrocytes in macrophages
Bilirubin is conjugated in the hepatocytes via the addition of two glycine molecules
The majority of bilirubin in bile is unconjugated bilirubin

questions.solution:
Bilirubin is the pigment that gives bile its color and is a byproduct of hemoglobin metabolism. The red blood cells are destroyed near the end of their lifespan by immune cells. Macrophages break down hemoglobin into heme and iron. Next, an enzyme called heme oxidase converts heme to biliverdin, which is green in color. Then, the enzyme biliverdin reductase converts biliverdin into bilirubin, which is yellow, and the bilirubin enters the blood. The bilirubin in the blood is not water-soluble and is referred to as unconjugated bilirubin. Albumin in the blood binds to the unconjugated bilirubin and transports it to the hepatocytes. Within the hepatocytes, the enzyme uridine glucuronyl transferase attaches the unconjugated bilirubin to glucuronic acid, turning it into conjugated bilirubin. The conjugation of bilirubin allows the bilirubin to become more water-soluble. As a result, conjugated bilirubin can be secreted into bile, whereas unconjugated bilirubin is typically not found in bile.  

Option Analysis

❌ The bilirubin released in the blood from macrophages is water-soluble.:
Incorrect: The bilirubin in the blood is not water-soluble and is referred to as unconjugated bilirubin. Albumin in the blood binds to the unconjugated bilirubin and transports it to the hepatocytes.   
✅ Uridine glucuronyl transferase conjugates the bilirubin in the liver:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilirubin is formed via glycosylation of erythrocytes in macrophages:
Incorrect: Bilirubin is formed via oxidation of heme by heme oxygenase in the macrophages  
❌ Bilirubin is conjugated in the hepatocytes via the addition of two glycine molecules:
Incorrect: The enzyme uridine glucuronyl transferase attaches the unconjugated bilirubin to glucuronic acid, turning it into conjugated bilirubin.   
❌ The majority of bilirubin in bile is unconjugated bilirubin:
Incorrect: Only conjugated bilirubin can be secreted into bile, whereas unconjugated bilirubin is typically not found in bile.
